direction.raw_text: A working-class funeral in progress. THIRTY PEOPLE and an inexpensive bier SEEN from the back of the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A MAN's back FILLS the SCREEN. He is dressed in a black suit; his hands are clasped behind him. ANOTHER MAN stands next to him. The Second Man reaches behind the First Man's back and puts a discreetly folded ten-dollar bill into his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These Two Men from the front. Both somber, in their early fifties. They begin to walk down the aisle of the funeral parlor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The WIDOW. A woman in her late fifties sitting by the bier receiving condolences. The Two Men approach her. The First Man (the recipient of the money) speaks:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Widow nods.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Dee, this is Frank Galvin -- a very good friend of ours, and a very fine attorney.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a shame about your husband, Mrs. Dee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I knew him vaguely through the Lodge. He was a wonderful man. (shakes head in sympathy) It was a crime what happened to him. A crime. If there's anything that I could do to help...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: removes a business card from his jacket pocket and hands it to her as if he were giving her money. (i.e., "Take it. Really. I want you to have it..." She takes the card. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shakes her hand and moves on.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (thoughtfully realizes he is usurping her time) Well...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galvin sitting in the deserted coffee shop in his raincoat. Reading a section of the paper. He picks up his teacup, drinks. Lowers it to the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin twists tea bag around a spoon to extract last drops of tea. His hand moves to his felt pen lying on the table. He moves his hand to the paper, open at the obituary section. We SEE several names crossed out. He circles one funeral listing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin sitting, raises cup of tea to his lips. Looks around deserted coffee shop. Sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin outside a second funeral home. WORKING-CLASS PEOPLE entering, Galvin enters the home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin, coming down the aisle toward the front, shrugging himself out of his overcoat, he approaches the BEREAVED WIDOW sitting by the front of the home, he extracts his card from his pocket, starts to speak. He is stopped by the WIDOW'S SON, a hefty man in his mid-forties, who interjects himself between Galvin and the widow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The FUNERAL MANAGER hurries down the aisle, and starts extricating Galvin from the commotion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is manhandling Galvin toward the back of the funeral parlor. The Son calls after him:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (of the card) What is that...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell is that...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I was a friend of your fa...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You never knew my father. (hits card out of Galvin's hand) You get out of here, who the hell do you think you are...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Funeral Manager) I'm talking to this man...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, Mrs. Cleary...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who the hell do you think you are?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Funeral Manager and Galvin standing in the cold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Funeral Manager gives Galvin a small shove, and goes back to his post at the door, greeting the entering mourners. "Good evening..."
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want you coming back here. Ever. Do you understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was just talking to...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Those are bereaved people in there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galvin, the ground cut out from under him. Standing watching the mourners enter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin walking down a residential street. He has been walking a while in the cold, snowy night. He stops for a stoplight at a corner, waits for the light although there is no traffic. Lights a cigarette. The light changes. He looks both ways and irresolutely starts across the street. He stops. He checks his watch. He sighs, and starts back in the opposite direction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin holding forth at the bar of a seedy drinking-man's establishment, THREE DRINKERS, acquaintances, standing around him, appreciative.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bartender, JIMMY, comes up to Galvin.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Pat says, 'Mike... there's a new bar, you go in, for a half a buck you get a beer, a free lunch, and then take you in the back room and they get you laid.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Another, Frank...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gestures to include group) ...everybody. Mike says, 'Pat, you mean to tell me for a buck you get a free lunch and a beer, and then you go in the back and get laid?' 'That's correct.' Mike says, 'Pat. Have you been in this bar ?' Pat says, 'No, but my sister has...' (gestures to Jimmy) Everyone. Buy yourself one too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The seedy, disorganized small office, Galvin in shirt-sleeves opening a file cabinet. He takes out an armload of files, carries them to a wastebasket and throws them in. He sits on his desk, as if exhausted by his effort, pours from a whiskey bottle into a large water glass, downs the glass. He has been drinking for some time. He starts stumbling back to the file cabinet. On the way his eye is caught by his degrees hanging on the wall. He stumbles to them, picks them up and walks over to the wastebasket and throws them in. He goes back to the file cabinet, the phone starts ringing. Galvin lets it ring, continues emptying the files into the wastebasket, tearing some of them up as he does so. He repeats softly to himself, as a litany, "It doesn't make a bit of difference, it doesn't make a bit of difference..." He starts back to the desk for the bottle, knocks the still- ringing phone off the desk. He pours himself a drink. As he downs it we hear -- softly -- from the phone on the floor: a MAN'S VOICE. "Frank. Frank. Frank. Goddamnit. Are you there...? Frank..." Galvin pays no attention. Drinks his drink and gazes at the wall -- now empty of degrees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - P.O.V. The empty wall. Galvin's P.O.V. The telephone heard Voice Over insisting, "Frank..."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a man in his late sixties, dressed in suit and overcoat, looking worried, unlocks the door to the dark anteroom. Looks around. Sees something in the next room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - P.O.V. Galvin asleep on his couch, clothed as before. Covered in his overcoat, the bottle and glass next to the couch on the floor, the sound of the phone off the hook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mickey walks into the office. Stands looking at Galvin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin wakes up. Looks around. Swings his legs over the couch. Drinks from the glass. Vacantly:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin pours himself a drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mickey walks to him, knocks the drink out of his hand and slaps him several times in the face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mickey walks out of the office. Slams the door. Beat. Galvin looks around the office. Goes to his sofa. Sits, reaches to side table.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (harshly) Get up. (beat, more harshly) Get up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, Mickey...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell do you think you're doing...? (surveys the wrecked office) What's going on here...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuck you. I got a call today from Sally Doneghy...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...now who is that...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...You're 'sposed to be in court in ten days and she's telling me you haven't even met with them...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sally Doneghy, now who is that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One lousy letter eighteen months ago... I try to throw a fuckin' case your way...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...hey, I don't need your charity...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I get these people to trust you -- they're coming here tomorrow by the way -- I get this expert doctor to talk to you. I'm doing all your fuckin' legwork -- and it's eighteen months. You're 'sposed to be in court. I bet you haven't even seen the file.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, what are you, my nanny?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen to me. Listen to me... listen to me, Frank, 'cause I'm done fuckin' with you. I can't do it any more. Look around you: You think that you're going to change? What's going to change it? You think it's going to be different next month? It's going to be the same. And I have to stop. This is it. I got you a good case, it's a moneymaker. You do it right and it will take care of you. But I'm through. I'm sorry, Frank, this is the end. (beat) Life is too short, and I'm too old. (beat)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The side table, a pack of Luckies. Galvin taking one, his hand shaking a little. Also on side table a pile of change containing a small rosary and a wedding ring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The carriage of a typewriter. A sheet of paper. Its letterhead reads "Frank P. Galvin. Attorney at Law, 124 State Street, Boston, Mass. 02981. Cable FRAGAL." Someone is typing, "Sorry I had to go out. Back at 10. Judge Geary called. Are you available for lunch Wednesday University Club?" A hand takes a paper from carriage and puts it on desk. Takes a pen and signs, "Claire."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin in the anteroom, dressed in his suit, unshaved, having just signed the paper. He takes a piece of Scotch tape from the dispenser on the desk, picks up a file folder from the coffee table. It is torn in several places and rudely Scotch- taped.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - P.O.V. - INSERT The file headed Deborah Ann Kaye v. St. Catherine Laboure Hospital et. al.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin surveys the anteroom, opens door to corridor, Scotch tapes the note he has just typewritten to the outside of the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dark paneling, clean, simple. A drinkers' bar. OLD BARTENDER and THREE CUSTOMERS spaced widely, Galvin in his overcoat downing a shot, the file open before him. He is reading. He checks his watch, scoops the file together under his arm, throws a dollar on the bar, and heads for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin walking tentatively down the corridor of a very rundown nursing home. He receives suspicious looks from the Attendants. He is checking numbers on the doors against a notation in the file. He finds the correct door and enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door to the ward from the inside. Galvin opening the door to the dark ward, backlit, tentative, a little unsteadied from his drinking. He puts his back against the door, puts down file and briefcase, extracts a small cheap Polaroid camera from the briefcase, readies it to shoot, picks up his paraphernalia, and starts off down the ward. As he walks down the ward he checks the file hung at the foot of each bed. Galvin stops at the foot of one bed and reads the chart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - P.O.V. The chart held by Galvin. DEBORAH ANN KAYE, various medical notations. He lowers the chart and we SEE in the bed beyond it a shriveled, tiny form stuck with needles and tubes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin replaces the chart, puts his file, briefcase, etc. on the foot of the bed, takes a flash photo of the figure in the bed. Takes another one. Puts down camera, sits on the end of the bed gazing at the unseen form. He lights a cigarette, and sits looking at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . A mousy woman in her forties is standing by a door on which is written, "Frank P. Galvin. Attorney at Law."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sally Doneghy points to the note on the door. Galvin takes it from the door. Reads. "Back at 10, Judge Geary. Lunch..."
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm... Mrs. Doneghy? I'm Frank Galvin... why didn't you go in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's locked.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (astonished) It's locked?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm terribly sorry... I hope we didn't put you out. Won't you come in...? (motions Sally into inner office, gestures with note) I'd offer you some coffee, but it looks like my girl just went out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galvin is perched at his secretary's desk. Sally Doneghy across from him by the coffee table listening intently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door to the corridor opens and DICK DONEGHY, a workingman in his forties, comes into the room. Sally and Galvin stand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Donegy and Galvin shake hands uncomfortably. He motions the two to sit.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's not a good case. It's a very good case.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A healthy young woman goes into the hospital to deliver her third child, she's given the wrong anesthetic...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...we, we love her, Dick and me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I'm sure you do...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But what can we do? She don't know who's visiting her...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I know. I went...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...You saw her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Yes, I have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know how beautiful she was? (beat) Her husband left her, and he took her kids... They, they, they'd let you die in there. They don't care. Nobody cares. The Patriot Home, the Chronic Care... in Arlington...? They'd take her in. Perpetual care. They'd take her. Fifty thousand dollars they want. An endowment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...fifty thousand dollars?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't want to leave her. Dick... the, the... and Father Laughlin, he said that it was God's will...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I understand...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My doctor told me that I got to move out West... that's when we filed in court. We didn't want to sue...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I understand...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...But Dick, he's looking for two years in Tucson... and they called him up and said to come out. He's a good man. He's only trying to do what's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is my husband.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please sit down. I told your wife. I'm sorry that we have to meet out here. I've got a case coming in two days in the Superior Court and my office is a mess of papers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...that's all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was telling your wife, we have a very good case here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He saw her at the Northern Care...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...and I have inquiries out to doctors, experts in the field... there is, of course, a problem getting a doctor to testify that another doctor's negligent...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...the Archdiocese called up, they said who was our attorney, 'cause the case is coming to trial...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I doubt we'll have to go to trial...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...we told them we didn't want it to come out this way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I completely understand...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We just...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We just can't do it anymore. (beat) This is our chance to get away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to see you get that chance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is this going to cost?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's completely done on a contingency basis. That means whatever the settlement is I retain one-third... that is, of course, the usual arrangement...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DAY Yellowed newspaper clipping, a very lovely, patrician woman in her twenties smiling at a well-turned-out Galvin around thirty. Headline: "Patricia Harrington to Wed."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A hand turns a page and reveals a second clipping: "Boston Lawyer Held in Jury Tampering Case," with a picture of a very confused Galvin at around forty-five being led to jail.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) His name is Frank Galvin. B.U. Law, class of 'fifty-two. Second in his class. Editor of the Law Review. Worked with Mickey Morrissey twelve years. Criminal Law and Personal Injury...'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Married Patricia Harrington, nineteen sixty...'
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The small, sumptuously appointed Italianate office. French windows, a fire in the grate, a view of Boston Common, JOSEPH ALITO, a slender, elegant man in his forties dressed in a very expensive suit, reading from his notes, news clippings, etc., which are held in a leather folder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alito, strolling as he reads, moves toward the windows with his file TO REVEAL BISHOP BROPHY, a self-contained man in his early sixties, sitting on a leather couch, listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Bishop nods, meaning, "You are dismissed." As an afterthought:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Alito, preparing to leave, reaches to the Bishop's desk, where he has laid his leather folder.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: 'Joined Stearns, Harrington, Pierce nineteen sixty as a full partner. Resigned the firm nineteen sixt-ynine over the Lillibridge case...' Do you...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was accused of jury tampering.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Accused. Not indicted. He resigned the firm. Divorced nineteen seventy. Galvin worked with Michael Morrissey until Morrissey retired in 'seventy- eight. Since then he's been on his own. Four cases before the Circuit Court. He lost them all. He drinks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Four cases in three years...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The man's an ambulance chaser...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...tell me about this case.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is a nuisance suit. He's looking for small change. He's asking for six hundred thousand and betting we don't want to go to court.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No -- we don't want this case in court.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Neither does he. That's where he loses. This man's scared to death to go to court. We only have to call his bluff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to settle this thing and be done with it. I don't want the Archdiocese exposed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Absolutely, and we're going to see that it is not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So what I want to do is stop it here. I'm going to make him an offer. I want to do it myself. I want it to come from me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right. But let's keep the price down. I've called Ed Concannon. He recommends that we continue to respond as if we're going to trial.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If we were to go to trial, would we win the case?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, of course, it's always dangerous...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know that answer. If we went to trial would we win?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in an "of course" tone) Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The clipping in the folder, confused Galvin being led into jail, "Boston Lawyer Held in Jury Tampering Case." Alito's hand snaps the folder shut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A man's arms full of textbooks. Prominently displayed: "Methodology and Practice in Anesthesiology." The man stops, fumbles for a key in his pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin, in his overcoat, arms full of books, reading from a textbook and trying to unlock his office door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin entering. CLAIRE PAVONE, a woman in her fifties, at the secretary's desk, hanging up the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin looks up at her in surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin nods, proceeds into his office, reading from the textbook. Claire follows him into the office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hands him typed memo slip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phone rings. Claire moves to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gestures to Galvin, "Do you want to talk to them?" Galvin gestures back, "No. I'm not in..."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks to Galvin, who nods, "yes."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hangs up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to phone) Thank you very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mickey told me to come back to work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...here's your mail, call Mrs. Doneghy...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...yes. Get her on the phone...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...that was a Dr. David Gruber's office...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (putting down books) Gruber...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mickey told him to call. (reading from notes) 'He's some very hotshot surgeon at Mass. Commonwealth. He wants to meet with you at seven tonight re testimony in the case of Deborah Ann Kaye. You meet him at the hospital.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surprised) ...he wants to testify...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It looks that way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what that would mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To get somebody from a Boston hospital to say he'll testify?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...a Mrs. Doneghy called... I told you that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (delighted) This is going to drive the ante up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (into phone) Frank Galvin's... who's calling please? Bishop Brophy's office...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, he's not in... may I take a mess... tomorrow when, two o'clock... I'll check my book...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Mr. Galvin's clear at that time... the Bishop's office, tomorrow, the fifth at two p.m. Thank you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the call that I'm waiting for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What does it mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They want to settle. (beat) It means a lot of money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Does that mean I'm back for awhile?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Man's wrist. WWII GI watch reads: 6:56.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin in overcoat standing outside door marked "Doctors Only" in bustling hospital corridor. He glances at memo slip in his hand. He opens door. CAMERA FOLLOWS him onto:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carpeted, small, comfortable, lined in lockers. A DOCTOR, on the phone in greens, smoking a cigarette, talking on the phone softly, a couple of DOCTORS sitting, drinking coffee, chatting. Galvin, a trifle nervous, to Doctor ON PHONE:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Doctor on the phone gestures behind him to a thirty-ish MAN in blue jeans smoking a cigar, changing at his locker. Galvin walks over to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He checks his watch, continues changing into suede jacket, checks next appointment on a leather appointment book, locks the locker, pockets key.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gruber, Galvin following, talk while exiting locker room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Gruber...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Gruber...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning) Yes? Galvin, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I appreciate -- a man as busy as -- GRUBER That's perfectly all right. I'm kind of rushed. Do you mind if we walk while we talk?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: I read the hospital report on your client.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They walk hurriedly through a hospital corridor, to an EXIT door and down concrete stairs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...Deborah Ann Kaye...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Deborah Ann Kaye...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They called, they're going to settle, what I want to do is build up as much...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gruber stops at the bottom of the stairs, beside an exit to the outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat. Gruber discards end of a cigar. Takes a leather case from his suede jacket, extracts a new cigar. Offers one to Galvin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin takes one absently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin, excited, is trying to light the cigar. His hand shakes badly. He has forgotten to bite off the end. He bites it, lights the cigar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to get a deposition..
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Right. Who called?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Archdiocese called, they want to settle... her estate...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...and you're going to do that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surprised, of course) Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're going to settle out of court?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (it's a meaningless question to him, as if to a child) Uh... in the, well, in the interests of her family... you, Dr. Gruber, you know, you can never tell what a jury is going to do. St. Catherine's a very well thought of institution. Her doctors...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (glances at watch, impatient) Her doctors killed her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a beat) I'm sorry...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Her doctors murdered her. They gave her the wrong anesthetic and they put her in the hospital for life. (a beat) Her doctors murdered her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know who her doctors were?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I read the file. Yeah. Marx and Towler. I know who they were.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The most respected...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) Whose side are you arguing...? I thought that you wanted to do something. I don't have any interest in the woman's 'estate' -- No offense, but we all know where the money's going to... I have an interest in the Hospital; and I don't want those bozos working in the same shop as me. They gave her the wrong anesthetic. They turned the girl into a vegetable. They killed her and they killed her kid. You caught 'em. Now: how many others did they kill?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want a cigar?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The hospital is owned by the Archdioceses of...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are they going to do? Not invite me to their Birthday party...? (checks watch) Look, I gotta go. I have to be in Cambridge...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, well, when can we meet again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. I'll meet you here. Tuesday night... I gotta go. You going my way?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gruber opens door and walks out into the cold, into the parking lot, followed by Galvin, who is lighting his cigar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They stop before a 1950s very beautiful small Mercedes Sedan. Gruber opens the door, gets into the plush red leather interior, starts car, leaves door open, still talking to Galvin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin scribbles information in his appointment book.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We have to... we... we have to keep you under wraps. Please don't, don't discuss...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...the case with anyone. And I'll meet you Tuesday, and we'll go over your testimony...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right. Seven o'clock. Here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...that's perfectly all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) Uh, why, why are you doing this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (thinks a second) To do right. Isn't that why you're doing it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galvin is at the bar, smiling to himself. His drink is being refilled. To BARTENDER:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin looks around. A very attractive self-possessed YOUNG WOMAN is sitting in the crook of the bar across from him; she is intently perusing the newspaper and circling items with a felt pen. Galvin speaks to her:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks up. Smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gestures at her own full glass in front of her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He watches her as she leaves the bar. He turns back to his drink.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I want to buy you a drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, Franky.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you like a drink?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like an apartment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Settle for a drink?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I had a very good day today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat, smiles, downs drink, gets up off the stool, sincerely) I'm glad you did. Thank you. Good night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're very welcome.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, well, well. Huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sighs) It's a long road that has no turning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's for sure, Frank.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A shoddy one-and-a-half room bachelor apartment. Galvin, beer and cigarettes on the table beside him. He is sitting on an armchair in the bedroom. A yellow legal pad in his lap. He is talking on the phone softly, soothingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His attention wanders to the legal pad in his lap.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to the Archdiocese tomorrow at two. I know you don't. I know you don't... no, you're just following your life. You have a life too... you have to move out West. It doesn't help you to stay here. Well... I'm sure she knows you care for her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - P.O.V. The legal pad. Spread on it a couple of Polaroids of Deborah Ann in the nursing home. Below them, written on the pad, large, "Dr. David Gruber. Ass't. Chief Anesthesiology, Mass. Commonwealth. 'They killed her. And they killed her kid -- Her doctors murdered her.'" The following figures are written on the pad: $150,000.00 written very large, circled, crossed out. $250,000.00 similarly circled and crossed out. $225,000.00 circled many times.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (voice over; on phone) Well. Well. Well. Finally we're none of us protected... we... we just have to go on. To seek help where we can... and go on... I know that you love her... I know you're acting out of love.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (into phone) As soon as I know... you give him my respects too. Not at all. Not at all... Good night. (beat) Well, bless you, too. Good night. He hangs up phone, sighs. Lights a cigarette. Rotates his neck to loosen it up. Reaches to the table next to his bed for the bottle to pour a drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His hand reaching for the bottle. On the table the photo of a very beautiful blonde woman in a silver frame. She is the same woman we saw earlier in the news clip. She is on the deck of a sailboat, laughing. A pile of change on the table, a money clip, a rosary, and the wedding ring in the pile of change.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin looking at the photo in the silver frame next to his bed. He sighs deeply. Beat. Reaches up to the lamp above his head and turns it off. He sits stiffly in the dark a moment, then lets his head fall back to the chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin, spruced up a bit, sitting on a bed, his briefcase on his lap. Gazing at the unseen Deborah Ann Kaye in the dark ward. Silent. Beat. He looks in his briefcase, takes out a file.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - P.O.V. - INSERT The file, labeled Deborah Ann Kaye. Galvin extracting the photo of the young mother romping with her two children; he takes the yellow legal pad from his briefcase and puts it on top of the picture (the figures crossed out; "Her doctors murdered her," etc.). We hear the door to the ward open and TWO IRISH WOMEN gossiping.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: #1 (V.O.) Jimmy, I said, don't you go in your pocket if there's nothing there...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 (V.O.) ...and what did he say...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 (V.O.) (spies Galvin, her tone changes) ...Sir, you aren't allowed to be in here...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galvin sitting on the bed looking at Deborah Ann. He looks up to the speaker. A slovenly Irish Nurse, who has come into the room and is standing by him. The other Nurse is framed in the doorway. Galvin is lost in thought.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You can't be in here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as if remembering something, simply) I'm her attorney.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Bishop from the waist up, sitting behind his beautiful desk. Compassionately:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's a question of continuing values. St. Catherine's -- to do the good that she must do in the community has to maintain the position that she holds in the community. So we have a question of balance. On the one hand, the reputation, and, so, the effectiveness of our hospital, and two of her important doctors -- and, on the other hand, the rights of your client.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galvin seated across from the Bishop. A YOUNG PRIEST seated, discreetly, attentively, across the room. Sherry glasses in front of Galvin and the Bishop. Galvin drinking from his.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin has been dreaming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gestures to the Young Priest, who crosses the room, extracts a sheet from a file folder, and places it before Galvin, who is sitting as if in a dream. The Bishop waits a beat, not wanting to interrupt Galvin's reverie, then catches his eye and gestures down at the paper. Galvin glances down.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A young woman. In her prime... deprived of... (searches for a word) ...life... sight... her family... It's tragic. It's a tragic accident.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...nothing, of course, can begin to make it right. But we must do what we can. We must do all that we can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The sheet: "I, Frank P. Galvin, duly appointed conservator for Deborah Ann Kaye, in consideration of Two Hundred Ten Thousand Dollars ($210,000.00) paid in hand to me this day by St. Catherine Laboure Hospital do hereby release from any and all claims..."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin and the Bishop as before. Galvin finishes reading, looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beat. Galvin nods. Beat. Bishop nods discreetly to the Young Priest who extracts Mount Blanc fountain pen from his pocket, holds it out to Galvin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A beat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. We must try to make it right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a generous offer, Mr. Galvin... (beat) ...nothing can make the woman well... but we try to compensate... to make a gesture...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How did you settle on the amount?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We thought it was just.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You thought it was just.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because it struck me how neatly 'three' went into the amount. Two Hundred Ten Thousand. That would mean I keep seventy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That was our insurance company's recommendation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. It would be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing that we can do can make that woman well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And no one will know the truth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is the truth?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That that poor girl put her trust in the hands of two men who took her life, she's in a coma, her life is gone. She has no family, she has no home, she's tied to a machine, she has no friends -- and the people who should care for her: her Doctors, and you, and me, have been bought off to look the other way. We have been paid to look the other way. I came in here to take your money. (beat) I brought snapshots to show you. So I could get your money. (to Young Priest, waving away document) I can't take it. If I take it. If I take that money I'm lost. I'm just going to be a rich ambulance chaser. (beat; pleading for understanding) I can't do it. I can't take it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If we may discuss money, Mr. Galvin. How is your law practice?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not too good. I've only got one client.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galvin, determined, coming down a corridor in the Courthouse, opens a door. CAMERA FOLLOWS him IN. The Lawyers Room. Ten or twelve AMBULANCE CHASERS waiting for clients. They all look up as he enters, then return to their reading, phones, card games. CAMERA FOLLOWS him TO the corner of the room where MICKEY MORRISSEY is playing Gin with a CRONY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin leads Mickey out of the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I have to talk to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dragging him up) Come on. Let's get a drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sighs, to partner) Don't touch anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mickey and Galvin silhouetted against a window at the end of the dark corridor, arguing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know who the attorney is for the Archdiocese, Eddie Concannon.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (enraged) Are you out of your mind...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I'm going to need your help...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You need my help...? You need a goddamn keeper... are you telling me that you turned down two-hundred-ten grand? (beat) Huh...? Are you nuts? Eh? Are you nuts. What are you going to do, bring her back to life?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to help her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To do what...? To do what, for chrissake...? To help her to do what? She's dead...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They killed her. And they're trying to buy it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's the point, you stupid fuck. Let them buy it. We let them buy the case. That's what I took it for. You let this drop -- we'll go up to New Hampshire, kill some fuckin' deer...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mick. Mick. Mick...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You -- Listen: you said to me, 'if not now, when...'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know what I said but not now. You won it. Franky. You won it. When they give you the money, that means that you won. We don't want to go to court -- is this getting to you...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...he's a good man...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...he's a good man...? He's the Prince of Fuckin' Darkness... he'll have people in there testifying that the broad is well -- they saw her Tuesday on a surfboard at Hyannis... don't fuck with this case.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I have to stand up for her...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frank, but not now. Frank. You're trying to wipe out some old business. But not now. I understand. But you go call 'em back. You call the Bishop back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have to try this case. I have to do it, Mick. I've got to stand up for that girl. I need your help. (beat) Mick, will you help me...? (beat) Will you help me...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A young ATTORNEY in shirt-sleeves and vest racing through a huge, ultra-modern, ultra-successful legal office. The office is near empty. A couple of secretaries are at their desks, a couple of lawyers in their cubicles. The CAMERA FOLLOWS the Attorney tearing through the corridors of the office, up a spiral staircase, through yet more office space, into:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...a conference room. Mahogany, tinted glass, a panoramic view of Boston. Twenty-five attorneys, male and female, mostly young, gaze at the young Attorney as he enters the room. He stops running. He approaches the front of the room tentatively. Standing at the blackboard in front of the conference room is EDWARD CONCANNON. Senior partner of the firm, late fifties, imposing, he radiates success. As the young Attorney approaches Concannon he is stopped with a gesture. Concannon addresses the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A young MAN raises his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Concannon motions to the young Attorney who has run in. The young Attorney goes to Concannon and hands him a box of chalk. Concannon takes a piece and writes on the blackboard "Jan. 12th." He underlines it heavily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The young Attorney responds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Concannon writes on blackboard "3) Public Awareness."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The young Lawyer stands as Concannon sits, listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the lawyers in the office turn in their files to that page.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) Anybody ever hear, 'For want of a shoe a horse was lost?' Who's going on vacation tomorrow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Friedman. St. Barts. is that right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yessir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to secretary taking notes at the side of the room) Send Mrs. Friedman a dozen roses tomorrow morning please, Sal. I tell you what, send her a sunlamp. (smiles, there is laughter from the room; to Friedman, sympathetic) I'm sorry, but you'll have to stay. No vacations till this thing is cleared.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Our court date is January twelfth. You're all acquainted with this case. It's been scheduled for eighteen months. We have the attorney for the Plaintiff, Frank Galvin -- and I trust you are all familiar with his record -- and we have been expecting him to call us to negotiate. As he did not, and five days before we're supposed to go to court we made him a rather generous offer, which he refused. Five days before the trial. What does this mean? I want to find out. (writes on the blackboard, "1) Research") (writes "2) Homework") Acquaint yourselves again with the depositions. Don't rely on the fact that we did it last year. Do it again. We're going to review them here, and you do it at home. You each have a full file. Know the deps, and I want you all to be here when we work with the defendants... when is that, Billy...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tuesday evening, Sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want an article in the Globe As Soon As Possible, 'St. Cat's... Neighborhood Giant serving the community' etc. We've got it in the files. I want something in Monday's Herald: 'Our Gallant Doctors,' something... Be inventive, I want television... (nods toward one of the young lawyers) ...talk to our man at GBH. And to belabor the obvious for a moment... (beat) Our clients are: the Archdiocese of Boston; St. Catherine Laboure Hospital, and Drs. Marx and Towler, two of the most respected men in their profession. The thrust of this defense will be to answer in court, in the press and in the public mind -- to answer the accusation of negligence this completely: not only that we win the case, but that we win the case so that it's seen that the attack on these men and this institution was a rank obscenity. (beat) All right. Let's get the cobwebs off. Billy...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please turn to your Page Four.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're going to start with a review of the depositions of the Operating Room Team: the nurse-anesthetist, the scrub-nurse, the...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galvin and Mickey at a library table piled with books. A dingy, dusty law library. They are smoking, speak in undertones, referring to the yellow legal pads in front of them. Rehashing material.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who have we got?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've got her sister. Testifies she had a meal one hour before she was admitted to the hospital. This is the point.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got the admittance form says patient ate nine hours prior to admittance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Admittance form is wrong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forget it. You can't prove it. Sister's testimony is no good. Jury knows we win she gets the cash.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got my Dr. Gruber, says her heart condition means they gave her the wrong anesthetic anyway, plus she came in complaining of stomach pains...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (conceding) ...Gruber's not bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not bad...? This guy's Dr. Kildare, the jury's going to love him, Mick... And you calm down, all right? Their guy, Towler's, the author of the book, (hunts for book on desk, holds it up; reads) 'Methodology and Practice, Anesthesiology.' (rummages through a pile of papers on the desk) ...and they got depositions from the nurses, everybody in the operating room, the scrub-nurse... 'All these guys are God. I saw them walk on water...' (checking a list) They had an obstetrical nurse in there. We got a deposition from the obstetrical nurse?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (checking list) No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reading from pad) 'Mary Rooney, forty-nine. Lives in Arlington, still working at the hospital.' Can you get out tomorrow? How come she isn't speaking up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay now. Cases: Smith versus State of Michigan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Brindisi versus Electric Boat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got a good memory, Franky.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I had a good teacher. McLean versus Urban Transport...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galvin and Mickey entering the bar, walk over to the bar. Galvin sees something O.S. Call to the bartender.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin motions with his head down at the end of the bar.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Jimmy? Bushmills. (turns to Mickey, whispers) Lookit, do me a favor. I'll buy you a drink tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah? And what are you going to do tonight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to get laid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - P.O.V. The Woman from last night, sitting in her same place at the end of the bar. Mickey looks at her. Shrugs. Gets up off stool.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He salutes, walks off. Galvin takes his drink and moves down to her.

direction.raw_text: She gets up from the stool and starts following him in spite of herself.

dialogue.raw_text: Don't leave your best work in the sheets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: D'you find an apartment?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Still looking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I changed my life today. What did you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I changed my room at the Hotel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The TV didn't work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What Hotel are you staying at?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what are you? A cop?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a lawyer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My ex-husband was a lawyer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Really. How wonderful for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. It was, actually.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, actually it was. Then why'd you call it off?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who says I'm the one that called it off?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A brick house says you divorced him. I'll put you on your honor. Bet you a hundred dollars against you join me for dinner. And I'll take your word for it. Now you tell me the truth. Because you cannot lie to me. What's your name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Laura.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My name's Frank. And furthermore, you came back to see me tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What if it wasn't you that I came back to see?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You just got lucky. (gets up off stool) D'you eat yet? Come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jesus, you are one beautiful woman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galvin and Laura are in a booth. The remains of a dinner and drinks around them. They are both smoking cigarettes, intent on each other. Both a little drunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin motions "another round" to the bartender.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The weak, the weak have got to have somebody to fight for them. Isn't that the truth? You want another drink?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jimmy! (beat) That's why the court exists. The court doesn't exist to give them justice, eh? But to give them a chance at justice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And are they going to get it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They might. Yes. That's the point... is that they might... you see, the jury wants to believe. They're all cynics, sure, because they want to believe. I have to go in there tomorrow to find twelve people to hear this case. I'm going to see a hundred people and pick twelve. And every one of them it's written on their face, 'This is a sham. There is no justice...' but in their heart they're saying, 'Maybe... maybe...'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat) Maybe I can do something right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And is that what you're going to do? (a beat) Is that what you're going to do...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what I'm going to try to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The bedroom, dark, sound of people moving, the bedside light is flicked on. We SEE Galvin in shirt-sleeves, holding a whiskey glass a little unsettled, turning on the light, Laura, with a glass, also a bit unsteady, standing beside him. Both awkward. He looks at her, turns back to the bed, turns down the bed, sees the silver-framed picture of his wife, he looks back at Laura, starts to take the picture to turn it down.

direction.raw_text: She starts taking off her blouse.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A half-full old-fashioned glass.

direction.raw_text: Galvin sitting at the fairly well-equipped bar, still. He looks out of the window at a building across the street.

dialogue.raw_text: . TOWLER She threw up in her mask.

dialogue.raw_text: ...and her heart stopped and she wasn't getting oxygen.

dialogue.raw_text: . TOWLER That's right.

dialogue.raw_text: . TOWLER Well, we...

dialogue.raw_text: . TOWLER Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...A patient riddled with complications, questionable information on her, on her admitting form...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . TOWLER ...We did everything we could...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...to save her and to save the baby. Is that...

dialogue.raw_text: . TOWLER Yes!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You reached down into death. Now, isn't that right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . TOWLER (getting overcome) My God, we tried to save her... You can't know... You can't know...

dialogue.raw_text: (changing tactics; soothing) Tell us.

dialogue.raw_text: Well, maybe you better do that, then. (starts to close door; stops) You know you guys are all the same. You don't care who gets hurt. You're a bunch of whores. You'd do anything for a dollar. You got no loyalty... no nothing... you're a bunch of whores.

Nineteen seventy-six got a courtesy appointment, staff of anesthesiology, Easthampton Hospital for Women. Never married. Has no honors or degrees of any weight. Since nineteen seventy- five he's testified in twenty-eight court cases, twelve malpractice. (smiles, saving his best 'til last) And he's black.

dialogue.raw_text: It's a terrible thing to sit in judgment. So much rides on it. I know that you've thought, 'How can I be pure. How can I be impartial without being cold. How can I be merciful and still be just?' And I know that most of you have said some sort of prayer this morning to be helped. To judge correctly. We have the reputation of two men. Two well respected doctors and a renowned hospital before us. And with those two respected men we have my client, Deborah Ann Kaye... (beat) ...who was deprived of sight, of locomotion, hearing, speech, of everything, in short, which constitutes her life. (beat) We are going to prove she was deprived through negligence. (beat) Through the negligence of those respected men. We will show: One...

dialogue.raw_text: Are you board-certified in anesthesiology, Doctor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON No, I am not. It's quite common in New York State...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...I'm sure it is, but this is Massachusetts, Doctor. Certified in Internal Medicine?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Neurology?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Orthopedics?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON I'm just an M.D.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know Dr. Robert Towler...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON I know of him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How is that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON Through, through his book.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What book is that?

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON Meth... Methodology and Technique...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...of Anesthesiology?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON 'Methodology and Techniques of Anesthesiology.' Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How old are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON I am seventy-four years old.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh-huh. Still practice a lot of medicine?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON I'm on the staff of...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, we've heard that. Doctor: you testify quite a bit against other physicians? Isn't that right? You, you're available for that? When you're paid to be there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON Sir. Yes. When a thing is wrong... as in this case, I am available. I am seventy-four years old, I am not board-certified.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON I have been practicing medicine for forty-six years and I know when an injustice has been done.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you, indeed. I'll bet you do. Fine. Fine. We'll save the court the time. We will admit the Doctor as an 'expert witness,' fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in undertone, to Bailiff) Do we have time this morning to... (glances at watch, Bailiff nods to him) All right. Mr. Galvin, you want to continue now, or we can resume with Dr. Thompson this afternoon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising) Thank you, your Honor, I'll continue. Dr. Thompson. Did you examine Deborah Ann Kaye last night at The Northern Chronic Care Facility?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON I did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Objection.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sustained. Yes. The witness will confine his testimony to review of the hospital records.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (patronizing) I believe that's the law... is it not, Mr. Galvin...?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dr. Thompson. From your review of the hospital records of May twelfth nineteen seventy-six.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In your opinion, what happened to Deborah Ann Kaye?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON Cardiac arrest. During delivery her heart stopped. When the heart stops the brain's deprived of oxygen. You get brain damage. That is why she's in the state she's in today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, Dr. Towler's testified that they restored the heartbeat within three or four minutes. In your opinion is his estimate correct?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON It's my opinion it took him much longer. Nine... ten minutes. There's too much brain damage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Dr. Thompson) Are you saying that a failure to restore the heartbeat within nine minutes in itself constitutes bad medical practice?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON Well...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your Honor!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Mr. Galvin?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I may be permitted to question my own witness in my own way...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd just like to get to the point, Mr. Galvin. Let's not waste these people's time. Answer the question, Mr. Witness. Please. Would a nine minute lapse in restoring the heartbeat in and of itself be negligence?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON I... in that small context I would have... I would have to say 'no.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you're saying there's no negligence, based on my question?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON I... given the limits of your question, that's correct.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Doctors were not negligent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON (beat) I... um...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galvin, furious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Judge and Witness.

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not through with the witness, your Honor. With all due respect if you are going to try my case for me I would appreciate it if you wouldn't lose it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you. I think that's enough for this morning. I'll see the Plaintiff's Counsel in my chambers. Now, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galvin, furious, standing against the wall. The Judge comes in from his own entrance, shucking his robe. Equally angry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin is pacing. Beat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I got a letter from the Judge Advocate's office on you today, fella, you're on your way out... They should have kicked you out on that Lillibridge case. Now this is it today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm an attorney on trial before the bar. Representing my client. My client, do you understand? You open your mouth and you're losing my case for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen to me, fella...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, you listen to me. All I wanted in this case is an even shake. You rushed me into court in five days... my star witness disappears, I can't get a continuance, and I don't give a damn. I'm going up there and I'm going to try it. Let the Jury decide. They told me Sweeney he's a hard- ass, he's a defendant's judge. I don't care. I said, the hell with it. The hell with it. I'll take my chances he'll be fair.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (conciliatory) Galvin, look, many years ago...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And don't give me this shit, 'I was a lawyer, too.' 'Cause I know who you were. You couldn't hack it as a lawyer. You were Bag Man for the Boys and you still are. I know who you are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (beat; barely controlling anger) Are you done?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Damn right I'm done. I'm going to ask for a mistrial and I'm going to request that you disqualify yourself from sitting on this case. I'm going to take a transcript to the State and ask that they impeach your ass.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You aren't going to get a mistrial, boy. We're going back this afternoon, we're going to try this case to an end. Now you get out of here before I call the Bailiff and have you thrown in jail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What does it mean? (beat) I... I mean we, you have other tactics...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We, yes. Yes. They, they present their side, and I get the same chance. To cross-examine... to... to...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are we going to win? (beat, desperately needing to trust) We have, you know, other tactics, though...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.

dialogue.raw_text: No further questions.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happened in those three...

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.

dialogue.raw_text: That's right.

dialogue.raw_text: And how the fuck... You broke the first law that they taught you in law school. You never ask a question you don't know the answer to. (beat) Frankie, wake up. You got your own expert witness says there was no negligence. It's over. Period. There'll be no other cases...

dialogue.raw_text: There are no other cases. This is the case. (beat) Now you decide... (beat) Are you in or out...?

dialogue.raw_text: I know how you feel. I know you don't believe me, but I do. I'm going to tell you something I learned when I was your age. I had prepared a case. Mr. White asked me, 'How did you do.' (beat) I said, 'I've done my best.' He said, 'They don't pay you to do your best. They pay you to win.' (beat) That's what pays for this office. (beat) And that's what pays for the pro bono work that we do for the poor. And for the kind of law that you want to practice. And that's what pays for your clothes and my whiskey, and the leisure that we have to sit back and discuss philosophy. (beat) As we're doing tonight. (beat) We're paid to win the case.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Interior office. Early morning. Galvin asleep with his head on his desk. Mickey asleep in a chair. Laura asleep on the couch, covered with Galvin's overcoat. Galvin wakes up, startled by the sound of the mail dropping. He picks up the phone mechanically. He realizes it is morning and he has been asleep. He replaces phone. He surveys the office. Dead, resigned. He closes the phone book. He reaches in a pack of cigarettes on the desk. It is empty. He roots in the ashtray for a long butt. This disgusts him. He rejects it. Rubs his eyes. Gets up. Goes to the window, stares out. Looks back at the scene in his office. It is over. He stands by Laura and looks down at her, he looks at Mickey. He has let them down. He goes to a cabinet under the lawbooks and takes out a bottle of whiskey and a water glass. He walks into the anteroom. Sighs, sits on the couch near the door. Glances at the several letters that have just fallen through the slot. He pours a half-tumbler full of whiskey, and drains it. He refills the tumbler. He absently picks up the mail and starts mechanically sorting through it. He stops at an official-looking piece.

dialogue.raw_text: Exception!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Noted. Thank you. (to Jury) Miss Costello was a rebuttal witness. Her sole rebuttal was the document, which has been disallowed...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galvin, silent, fuming, sitting at the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin takes a sheet of legal paper and starts writing on it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Her entire testimony must be stricken from the record. You shouldn't have heard it, but you did. Now, that was my mistake... and you must strike it from your minds, give it no weight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Legally it's over. Concannon was brilliant.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me about Kaitlin Costello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's nothing to tell. It's been stricken from the record.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. Did you believe her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: All looking slightly to their right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: JUDGE SWEENEY Mr. Galvin...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In front of the full jury box. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stands still a moment, then surveys the still courtroom.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You know, so much of the time we're lost. We say, 'Please, God, tell us what is right. Tell us what's true. There is no justice. The rich win, the poor are powerless...' We become tired of hearing people lie. After a time we become dead. A little dead. We start thinking of ourselves as victims. (pause) And we become victims. (pause) And we become weak... and doubt ourselves, and doubt our institutions... and doubt our beliefs... we say for example, 'The law is a sham... there is no law... I was a fool for having believed there was.' (beat) But today you are the law. You are the law... And not some book and not the lawyers, or the marble statues and the trappings of the court... all that they are is symbols. (beat) Of our desire to be just... (beat) All that they are, in effect, is a prayer... (beat) ...a fervent, and a frightened prayer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In my religion we say, 'Act as if you had faith, and faith will be given to you.' (beat) If... If we would have faith in justice, we must only believe in ourselves. (beat) And act with justice. (beat) And I believe that there is justice in our hearts. (beat) Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Laura in the corridor, watching him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Jurors filing in from the Jury Room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Concannon, Young Lawyer, Dr. Towler, Dr. Marx at Defense table. Young Lawyer scribbles a note, passes it to Concannon, who ignores it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Plaintiff's table. Galvin looking at the Jury, Mickey at the other end of the table.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Have you reached a verdict?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) We have, your Honor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Jury Box. The Jurors seated, the FOREMAN standing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Your Honor, we have agreed to hold for the Plaintiff... but on the size of the award, are we bound...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are not bound by anything, other than your good judgment, based on the evidence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galvin, totally defeated. Nods his head sadly, as if commiserating philosophically, with himself. Mickey looks at him in grief, with sympathy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin slowly raises his head, turns and looks at the Jury, Mickey begins to smile.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Are we permitted to award an amount greater than the amount the Plaintiff asked for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. You are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .O.V. The courtroom, commotion.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Please retire and...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Galvin and Mickey standing near a back staircase, cleaning equipment is lying all around. A large, battered garbage can. Mickey is lighting Galvin's cigarette. Galvin's hand shakes badly. Something draws his attention at the end of the corridor. He turns his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - P.O.V. Laura, standing at the end of the corridor. Tentative, lost, pleading silently, she holds a sheet of yellow legal paper in her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - LAURA'S P.O.V. THE PAPER READS: 'Laura. I'm going to try. When this is over can we go away?' 'Joe' 'Thank you'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .O.V. Laura holding the paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin and Mickey looking at her. Galvin's face impassive. Beat. He turns his back on her. Mickey does likewise. Beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beat. Galvin puts his arm around Mickey's shoulder. They push through the Exit Door, turning up their collars to the cold. Galvin hesitates a moment as Mickey goes through the door. Beat. He looks back longingly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Galvin) The jury might be out for awhile. (beat; tentatively) You want to run across the street and get a drink?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .O.V. The deserted corridor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Galvin standing framed in the doorway. He turns toward the door, his back to the CAMERA, his shoulders slumped. He stands for a moment, sighs, straightens up, and walks through the door.
direction.name: direction
